title: Get the ultimate guide to cozy reading
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Boston.com's free Cozy Books newsletter offers five daily emails with curated reading recommendations.
The guide features different cozy genres, including small-town charm, gothic mystery, and heartwarming romance.
Recommendations come from local booksellers and community writer Annie Jonas, aiming to provide comforting reads.

title: Want to help fight hunger in Boston? Here are 5 ways to do it.
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Donate to the Greater Boston Food Bank to help provide meals across Eastern Massachusetts.
Volunteer at East Boston Community Soup Kitchen to serve meals and donate essential supplies.
Contribute spices to the Boston Public Library Spice Bank to support cultural food traditions.

title: As injuries linger, Patriots rookie Kyle Williams could be poised for breakout opportunity
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots wideout Kayshon Boutte remains sidelined due to a hamstring injury, affecting deep ball strategies for Sunday's game.
Rookie Kyle Williams could see increased playtime with Boutte's absence, despite having caught only two passes this season.
Coaches Josh McDaniels and Mike Vrabel express confidence in Williams, highlighting his readiness for a larger role.

title: What songs are on your ‘divorce playlist’?
author: Meredith Goldstein
bullets: Meredith Goldstein discusses the distinction between breakup and divorce songs in her Love Letters newsletter.
Goldstein highlights songs by Sinead O'Connor, Outkast, and Paul Simon as examples of impactful divorce songs.
Lily Allen's new album addresses her divorce, highlighting personal challenges and societal expectations.

title: 10 days after their ugliest loss of year, Bruins are looking like a very different team
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Boston Bruins won five consecutive games following a 7-2 loss to Ottawa Senators, improving their record significantly.
First-year coach Marco Sturm attributes the team's recent success to improved defensive play and adherence to his system.
Key players like Charlie McAvoy and Marat Khusnutdinov have been crucial in Bruins' victories, contributing to overtime and shootout wins.

title: Did you follow the local news this week? Take our Greater Boston news quiz.
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston.com offers a quiz to test knowledge of trending local news stories in Greater Boston.
Peter Chianca has been Boston.com's general assignment editor since 2019.
The quiz aims to help readers stay informed about local events and news coverage.

title: Tripadvisor to cut 20% of staff amid internal restructuring
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Tripadvisor plans to cut 20% of its workforce as part of a strategic restructuring effort.
The company is merging its Tripadvisor and Viator brands to focus on experience-driven growth and AI integration.
Restructuring includes an $85 million cost-savings program anticipated to extend through 2027.

title: An abandoned tent has spurred a hiking mystery in New Hampshire
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: A tent found abandoned in New Hampshire's White Mountains has puzzled local hikers and officials.
The tent, discovered at Valley Way site, contained wet gear and food; no footprints were found nearby.
Items included a sleeping bag, car keys, and an Apple AirTag, but no missing persons were reported.

title: Local obituary: Susan Hurley, 62, former Patriots cheerleader who founded CharityTeams
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Susan Hurley, 62, founded CharityTeams in 2008, raising $42 million for nonprofits through athletic events like the Boston Marathon.
A former Patriots cheerleader, Hurley trained marathon runners for 18 years, hosting events like Superhero 17 and Hop 21.
A Celebration of Life for Susan Hurley will be held on November 8 at Waters Church Norwood, followed by a reception.

title: Market Basket launches its own beer — here’s where to buy it
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Market Basket has partnered with Vermont's Zero Gravity Beer to launch its own lager called 'More For Your Dollar'.
The 12-pack 'More For Your Dollar' lager is priced at $12.99, available in Massachusetts, Maine, and New Hampshire.
The launch follows a period of transition for Market Basket after CEO Arthur T. Demoulas was ousted.
